greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = number of run-lengths that each occur only once in the binary representation of n.
link: Gheorghe Coserea, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 92 in binary is 1011100. There is a run of one 1, followed by a run of one 0, then a run of three 1's, then finally a run of two 0's. The run lengths are therefore (1,1,3,2). The values of these run lengths that each only occur once are (3,2). Since there are 2 values that occur once, then a(92) = 2.
program: v = valuation(n,2); listput(bag, v); n >>= v; n++;
v = valuation(n,2); listput(bag, v); n >>= v; n--);
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Sep 17 2009
